p: Zinc (Zn) is an essential microelement with an important role in many physiological processes [ 97]. A deficiency can cause a number of health problems, so it is essential to ensure an adequate intake, mainly through a balanced diet containing both animal and plant products, but also by addressing factors that can impede the absorption of this element. Zinc can be supplied in food products ( Table 1) or in the form of dietary supplements [ 26, 97, 98]. The element has been shown to be present in all human tissues and body fluids. The average content of this element in an adult is 2â€“3 g [ 97, 99]. Zinc is present in the muscles, bones, skin and liver, as well as in the brain, kidneys, spleen and pancreas [ 97, 99, 100, 101]. The skin is the third most Zn-abundant tissue in the body, with greater amounts in the epidermis than in the dermis [ 99, 102]. In the epidermis, zinc is more abundant in the stratum spinosum than in the other layers of keratinocytes, while in the dermis, the zinc concentration is higher in the upper parts than in the deeper areas [ 102, 103].
